awd_titl_txt: Thrombospondin-1/calreticulin binding in regulating cell intermediate adhesion and collagen expression
awd_abstract_narration:
1159859
Song

Intellectual Merit. The research objective is to elucidate the fundamental structural and molecular mechanisms involved in formation of the ternary complex of the matricellular protein thrombospondin-1 (TSP1), the cell surface protein calreticulin (CRT), and LDL receptor-related protein 1 (LRP1) which is induced by TSP1 binding to cell surface CRT and which signals intermediate adhesion, cell migration, anoikis resistance, and collagen production. Wound healing in response to injury requires well-coordinated integration of the complex biological and molecular events associated with cell adhesion, cell migration, and extracellular matrix remodeling. Binding of TSP1 to cell surface CRT promotes binding of CRT to LRP1 to form the TSP1-CRT-LRP1 ternary complex, which is important for cellular events critical for wound healing and tissue repair. Although the importance of TSP1 and CRT interactions for cell functions related to tissue repair and remodeling are clear, the specific structural and molecular mechanism by which TSP1 engagement of CRT initiates signaling complex formation with LRP1 remains unclear. The PI will use the integration of computational modeling and biochemical and biological experimental approaches to implement the research objective. 

Broader Impact. The educational objective is to educate and retain graduate, undergraduate, high and middle school students, broadening the participation of minority and female students in science and engineering in a sustainable fashion, and to integrate the education, outreach and knowledge dissemination with the research activities. Successful completion of the proposed project will have a transformative impact on research, educational, and outreach activities. Research discoveries regarding structural and molecular mechanisms of the role of the TSP1-CRT interactions in regulation of CRT-induced TSP1-CRT-LRP1 ternary complex formation and subsequent regulation of intermediate adhesion and collagen expression and deposition could lead to the identification of novel strategies and drug targets for modifying aberrant tissue repair responses that occur in scarring or the foreign body response or conversely in wound healing deficiencies. The educational efforts will recruit and sustain talented and diverse students at multiple levels (graduate, undergraduate, high and middle school) who are excited about science and engineering and who possess a desire to succeed, will help to promote diversity in the science and engineering workforce, and will promote the knowledge dissemination.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. The matricellular protein thrombospondin-1 (TSP1) is present at wounds and is expressed by cells involved in wound healing. TSP1 engages in diverse cellular activities through its interactions with multiple receptors, including calreticulin (CRT) and LDL receptor-related protein 1 (LRP1). Binding of TSP1 to cell surface protein CRT promotes binding of CRT to LRP1 to form the TSP1-CRT-LRP1 ternary complex, which is critical for signaling intermediate adhesion, cell migration and anoikis resistance. For the awarded project, we have investigated the effect of lipid bilayer environments on TSP1 and CRT interactions via atomically detailed molecular dynamics simulations. Results showed that TSP1 binding to CRT resulted in a more "open" conformation for CRT N-domain with respect to the CRT P-domain in a raft-like lipid bilayer environment. This study provides molecular insights into the role of lipid bilayer environments in TSP1-CRT interactions and in the CRT conformational changes that could facilitate CRT binding to LRP1 to engage downsteam signaling events. To overcome computational cost limitation for long timescale all-atomic molecular dynamics simulations, we have further adopted a multiscale modeling approach of combining all-atomic molecular dynamics, coarse-grained molecular dynamics, and reversed all-atomic molecular dynamics simulations to investigate the interactions of single CRT or of the TSP1-CRT complex with a membrane microdomain at microsecond timescale. This study provides structural and molecular insights into TSP1-CRT interactions in a membrane microdomain environment and demonstrates the feasibility of using multiscale simulations to investigate the interactions between protein and membrane microdomains at a long time scale. We predicted the potential LRP1 binding site and key residues in TSP1-bound CRT for CRT-LRP1 binding using combined conformational analyses and hydropathy analyses. We investigated the effect of CRT key residue mutations on the conformational and dynamical motion changes of CRT via atomic molecular dynamics simulations. Results provide molecular insight into the effect of the CRT key residue mutations on CRT conformational and dynamical motion changes, which could influence CRT binding to LRP1 to signal the important cellular activities.

Broader Impacts. We have established a "learning chain" approach to engage students at the graduate, undergraduate and high school levels in learning through research and multidisciplinary collaborations to inspire the students' passion for science and engineering. We have collaborated with University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB) NSF REU program to provide research opportunities for undergraduate student as summer research assistant, partnered with UAB's Center for Community Outresearch Development (CORD) program to provide research opportunities for minority high school and undergraduate students as summer research interns, and provided high school student research opportunity through collaboration with local high schools and through the UAB Biomedical Engineering Summer Camp. With the research training with us, most of the high school students have continued their education into college, and most of the undergraduate students have enrolled in graduate schools or other professional schools. We have actively recruited and retained minority and female undergraduate and graduate students to participate in the awarded project.

Dissemination of Results. We disseminated our research findings to the scientific community by presenting our results in a timely manner. We have presented our results in national and international conferences and published our results in peer-reviewed quality journal. We integrated our research findings to the undergraduate level and graduate level courses that the PI taught to disseminate the research discoveries. Further, we provided research opportunities for graduate students, undergraduate students and high school students to disseminate the exciting results to these students.
